document_title: Psoriatic arthritis: Causes, symptoms, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA) is an inflammatory arthritis that occurs in some patients with psoriasis. The initial symptoms of psoriasis often start from skin lesions such as a red, scaly rash, often appearing on the patient's elbows, knees, ankles, hands and feet.
Most cases of psoriatic arthritis develop from psoriasis
Joint pain, stiffness and swelling in the joints are typical symptoms of the disease. The disease can affect any organ in the body, from the fingers, spine to the digestive system, with severity ranging from mild to severe.
There is currently no definitive treatment for psoriatic arthritis. Interventions are mainly aimed at controlling symptoms, preventing structural damage, and preventing dangerous complications to the musculoskeletal system. In cases where the disease is detected late, not properly treated can "disable" the patient's entire joint system.
